description:
The Arizona Elegans, also known as the Glossy Snake, is a species of non-venomous snake native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the genus Arizona, which is part of the larger family Colubridae.

The Arizona Elegans is a slender, medium-sized snake that typically ranges from 18 to 36 inches in length. It has a smooth, glossy appearance and a coloration that can vary from tan, gray, or reddish-brown, often with darker blotches or bands along its body. The snake's head is small and distinct from its neck, and its eyes are relatively small.

These snakes are known to be primarily nocturnal and terrestrial, spending much of their time on the ground in search of prey, which includes small rodents, lizards, and other small vertebrates. They are skilled burrowers and often utilize the abandoned burrows of other animals as their own shelter.

The Arizona Elegans is considered a relatively docile species and is not known to be aggressive towards humans. They play an important role in the ecosystem, helping to control populations of small prey animals and serving as a food source for larger predators.
